marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Richard Hill was a Charleston, South Carolina, merchant.

Letter book (89 p.) kept on a trip to England. Correspondence is with English merchants, ship's captains, bankers, and others connected with the South Carolina trade, concerning the colony of Georgia, the West Indian trade, commodity prices in English markets, and reports of the discovery of a silver mine in the Cherokee country 300 miles from Charleston.

Letters to William and Samuel B. Hines of Virginia, pertaining to privateering, relations of the United States with England, the embargo, New England's opposition to the War of 1812, and the election of 1836. Among the correspondents are Richard Blow, Thomas Gholson, Edwin Gray, John Hamilton, and John Young Mason.
Samuel Hodgdon was a colonel in the Pennsylvania militia, and a resident of Philadelphia, Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania.
Letters to Hodgdon from Clement Biddle, quartermaster of Pennsylvania, concerning supplies for the troops engaged in suppressing the Whiskey Rebellion.
R. F. Hinman letter, Salembridge, Connecticut, to Robert Breckinridge Mcafee,
Letter concerns the likelihood of success for the pro-Jackson Democratic forces in Kentucky and Connecticut in the upcoming election.

Letter to Betty Hobson from her brother Edward at Boydton, Va., where he is apparently a college student. The letter contains references to religious controversy involving Cambellites and Union Baptists.
Unprocessed collection. Cataloged from accession records.
Henry W. Hilliard was a U.S. representative from Alabama; Confederate general, and attorney.

Miscellaneous correspondence of Hilliard, including a letter, 1860, to Harper and Brothers expressing optimism about Alabama's chances of remaining in the Union; a letter, 1868, to Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase referring to hearings on the proposed trial of Jefferson Davis and mentioning the visit of Kate Chase Sprague and William Sprague, former governor of Rhode Island to Augusta, Ga.; and responses to autograph collectors.
Elizabeth Sherman Hoar was a resident of Concord (Middlesex County), Massachusetts.

Manuscript and typescript record of Elizabeth's trip to Charleston, South Carolina, with her father, Samuel Hoar, who was sent by the governor of Massachusetts to test the constitutionality of certain laws in South Carolina under which free blacks from Massachusetts, serving as seamen on vessels trading at ports in South Carolina, were seized, imprisoned, and sometimes sold as slaves.
Letter to David Hoffman from Robert Walsh, consul general of the United States in Paris, concerning Hoffman's essay on the formation of a British and American land and emigration company.
W. O. Hoffman was a student at Dickinson Commercial College's Cumberland, Maryland, branch.

These three volumes are exercise books from Hoffman's studies in bookkeeping and accounting. They include a journal, daybook, and cashbook. These volumes date from about the 1870's, or perhaps somewhat later. The handwritten examples in the exercises are dated 1850's and 1870's, mostly the latter. The paper has watermarks of 1850. The covers of the volumes were printed by the Cumberland Daily News Co. According to the AMERICAN NEWSPAPER ANNUAL (1891), the CUMBERLAND DAILY NEWS was established in 1871. These facts indicate that the volumes date from the postbellum rather than the antebellum period, despite the use of paper from 1850.
Himelius M. Hockett was a resident of Center, Randolph County, North Carolina.
Papers of Himelius M. Hockett, including miscellaneous bills and receipts; a practice writing tablet of Susannah Hockett; and a personal daybook of expenditures, 1855-1898.
Robert Bruce Hoadley was a Union soldier in the 26th Iowa Regiment, from Comanche (Clinton County), Iowa.
Letters of a soldier describing his service at the siege of Vicksburg and with the army of General William T. Sherman in Georgia and South Carolina.

John W. Hodnett was a Confederate soldier in the 13th Regiment of the Georgia Volunteers. He was a resident of Meriwether County, Georgia. There are several John Hodnetts from that county, so it is difficult to provide more information about him. T. J. Hodnett was born in 1845 in Henry, Georgia, and also served in the same regiment. The relationship between these two men is unclear.

Collection consists of letters from John W. Hodnett to his sister, with comments on the hardships of war and the various campaigns in which he was engaged. He discusses cooking in camp and the lack of food food in general, his lack of shoes, the absence of tents, the position of Union troops and taking prisoners, the defense of Richmond, his desire for the war to end. There is one letter from T. J. Hodnett, who writes to his father, discussing the battle at Gettysburg and his regret that Vicksburg has fallen, along with his religious attitudes regarding the war.
E. B. Hitt was a resident of Augusta, Georgia.
Business letters concerning the purchase of property.
Thomas P. Hoge was a resident of Halifax County, Virginia.

A letter from Thomas P. Hoge concerning his efforts to have his plantation overseer exempted from military service in 1863; a family letter from his sons, Whit and Moses, Confederate privates, 1863; and a letter from his wife, Mary C. Hoge, revealing her anxiety for the safety of her sons, 1864.
Oscar P. Hill was a sutler who followed and sold goods (tobacco, paper, etc.) to Union soldiers during the Civil War.

This collection consists of seven letters, all of which are addressed to Hill's partner William Barnes. The four letters of 1865 are from Nashville, Tennesee, and Decatur, Alabama, and concern the sutlery business. In 1867, Hill was in Nashville, his occupation unclear. His letter of Aug. 1 concerns the political and electoral situations there, including disfranchisement.
Miss Hilton was an English orphan. Niece of Reverend Rennell Molesworth.

Manuscript diary of a 20-year-old woman, Christian name unknown, of Uxbridge, England. The author occasionally expressed dissatisfaction with her living situation with her aunt and uncle, but most frequently wrote of her social life and drawing and painting lessons. Many passages have been excised.
Sarah Catherine Himes was a Russell County, Alabama, resident.

Collection contains personal letters, chiefly of Sarah Himes, addressed to her Uncle Adam Himes, who lived near Waynesville, N.C. There are references to conditions of crops, prices, Reconstruction, African-Americans in the legislature, and labor conditions. A few of the letters are from Eliza (Himes) Range and Jacob Range concerned with inquiries as to the whereabouts of various Himes family members.
Thomas Hobbs was a resident of Petersburg, Virginia.
Accounts from Hurt, Todd, & Gee for mackerel, whiskey, and miscellaneous articles and accounts of tobacco sales in Dinwiddie County, Virginia.

Ebenezer R. Hoar ) was an American politician, lawyer, and justice from Massachusetts. He was appointed U.S. Attorney General in 1869 by President Ulysses S. Grant; he became the first U.S. Attorney General to head the newly created Department of Justice in July 1870.
Letter to Hoar from Secretary of the Tresury George Sewall Boutwell, concerning laws designed to prevent the spread of disease from foreign countries among cattle in the United States.
John D. Hodges was a resident of Monroe, North Carolina.
Ledger for the Monroe High School, Monroe, North Carolina, 1875-1878, and one undated list of cotton production.
Minnie A. B. Hodgson was a resident of New Orleans, Louisiana.
Miscellaneous items including a manuscript article by John C. Potts, 1875; a letter of Thomas R. Markham, 1879; and several clippings.
J. D. Hodges was professor of Greek and modern languages at Trinity College, Randolph County, North Carolina, and teacher in the public schools.
Correspondence of Hodges with James T. LeGrand, lawyer of Rockingham, North Carolina, concerning business matters and Hodge's desire for an appointment at the University of North Carolina.
Two eye-witness accounts of the capture and imprisonment of Jefferson Davis.
